Posts.Content: Mar 19, 2012 05:27PM JustJudi wrote: My daughter was Stage 111 when diagnosed and was also pregnant, The Drs. wanted her to terminate at the time, because then they could throw everything at her in the way of treatment. She chose to go through with the pregnancy and gave birth to a little boy, she had chemo during the pregnancy , leaving out the harsher chemo until after she gave birth. She had the same thoughts was it fair to have a child who may lose their mother at an early age, as she has an aggressive form, but they wanted another child and they are happy with their decision, you cant put your life on hold, in case of the what ifs. a child could lose their parent because of an auto accident, things in life are not guaranteed. If you can have some joy in your life, live your life to your ability, go for it.  I wish you all the best.
Posts.Title: Pregnancy after Stage IV diagnosis Jejik CAROLINE77

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2011 11:41PM JustJudi wrote: Congrats on being Stable, Best of luck with stones, hope this gets resolved.
Posts.Title: PET Results Ready2Win Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2014 01:16PM JustJudi wrote: I was on Aromosine for 3 years  before it guit working, even though I had blood work every month, it  was not caught fast enough, I actually had a fracture of my arm and leg within a few months, before I was put on Xeloda. But I was also on Aredia, and had been taken off six months before, because they said it was ineffective after 2 years.  Now I am back on Aredia with the Xeloda, which is working for me.  I would keep pesting what ever department you need to , to get the medication approved. and get her on a cource of new treatment.  Thankfully my drugs our covered in manitoba.  But my husband had to get approval for one of his drugs, from provincial health, to cover the cost.  We found that his doctor was really the one that managed to get it approved faster.  So I would call the Doctors office back or the provincial dept that deals with the pharmacare part, and just keep bitching. I have really found we have to really advocate for ourselves.    Best of luck   judi
Posts.Title: 10 day break from Xeloda amd Femara buburuzaa GoldenGirls

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2011 09:57AM JustJudi wrote: Congratulations, on NEd, keep up the dancing.  Great News

Posts.Content: JustJudi wrote: I just finished 5 treatments of radiation on upper spine for pain relief from spinal mets, but both arms are inflamed so bad, I can barely move them from elbows up, I have tried aleve, advail, oxneo, codeine and frozen peas but ever day is the same for four days now. has anyone ever had this and have any suggestions for relief.  I can barely feed myself, the only thing i can do is use my fingers with the computor resting on my lap. good excuse not to do anything, but it is so painful Dx 8/18/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 1/2 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2+ Hormonal Therapy 10/8/2009 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 2/6/2010 3DCRT: Bone Radiation Therapy 6/10/2012 Bone Chemotherapy 9/5/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: inflamed arms after radiation, Help! JustJudi cookie97

Posts.Content: JustJudi wrote: Well good news, my daughter who was diagnosed in Aug, with TN Stage 3 just gave birth yesterday two months premature to a beautiful little boy, he is only 3lbs, 3 ounces, but is doing really good, she had 4 rounds of chemo and a real rough time in this pregnancy, the baby is able to breath on his own, and drs., say he is doing well. will have to spend about 8 weeks in hospital.  I just wish physically I could be more of a help to her , but just don.t have the strength, She was lamenting that she felt bad the other day on Valentines that all the other kids were bringing cookies and cupcakes to school and she just didnt have the energy to do the same. I think this is one of The more emotional trials of cancer, not being the mothers we want to be.  Its hard to look after yourself when you are more worried about looking after children.  BUT JOY A NEW BABY Dx 8/18/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 1/2 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2+ Hormonal Therapy 10/8/2009 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 2/6/2010 3DCRT: Bone Radiation Therapy 6/10/2012 Bone Chemotherapy 9/5/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2011 10:39AM JustJudi wrote: When I started this journey, my tumor markers were in 1800 range, I was put on aromasine, and have been on it for about 15 months, since then my markers have dropped to 150 and I have had healing in quite a few spots on ribs, spine.  I am leaving chemo for when the hormonal fail.  I think it depends on quite a few things,  age,  ER+ status etc.  I hope you and your Onc. can reach a discussion that is right for both of you.

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 09:39AM JustJudi wrote: So Sorrry for the loss of another beautiful lady, my deepest sypathy to her family . She will be missed.
Posts.Title: A sad update on Suze 35 Suze35 Janie-bug

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2013 12:27PM JustJudi wrote: Dear Chickadee congratulations on the news on being stable. I am on Xeloda, and every once in a while the Dr. takes me off it for a month until My blood gets built up again or I am over colds and flu the last time. My markers seem to stay within the same range when I am off for six weeks , but then at times can go crazy. I know I feel a lot better when I am off treatment, so I get to the point at times when I just feel like quitting for a while and seeing what happens, as my onc. always ask me if I want to keep on it and leave it up to me. I know at some point I will say no. I think that if she is willing to keep on top of your progress with blood work and make sure everything is still stable, I might just take the chance and be happy with not having chemo for a while. But I would always want to be monitored to make sure it wasnt progressing. It's a hard choice, because we just want to feel healthy and not feel like crap all the time. We have to do what works for us, and be joyful in the moments when we here good news for a change. So enjoy the moment.
Posts.Title: Completely stymied, but also happily surprised. HELP. Chickadee chrissyb

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 11:33AM JustJudi wrote: In 2009, I bent over my dishwasher and broke a rib, then not even 4 weeks later I lifted something heavy and broke a rib on my other side. This was what led to my diagnosis, I asked my Dr. why my ribs were just breaking from doing minor tasks. Finally PT and CT skans dio, breast cancer with mets to ribs, spine etc.   The trouble with ribs is they have to heal by themselves, and this took quite a while.  Don,t lift heavy objects, and be careful bending etc. Drs now don,t bind ribs for fractures, but I say if it helps go ahead, only make sure they are not to tight, as it may push the broken end out of alignment.  Pain meds are about the only help.
Posts.Title: Severe rib pain cmhartley sincitydealer

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2010 09:25AM JustJudi wrote:  I am glad to know that I am not the only one out their with these feelings.  Sometimes I feel quite alone.  We go from everyone waiting on us and helping when we are quite ill, to wow , you have recovered and every thing is back to normal.  I have started during my housework again, what I can, cooking meals and resumed driving and going to do some shopping.  I still need my cane and carts to get me around, and help in unloading groceries, last week my 85 year old neighbor neighbor came over and helped carry groceries in with me. My adult children and DH just seen like , hey everything is good again you are better.  I don't like to tell them I feel crappy some days, because my daughter in law , told me everyone had such a hard time dealing with the news when I was first diagnosed with stage 4, So I find its better to keep it to myself, I can see why caregivers have a hard time knowing how much to do and whether they should be helping, because I have did the same thing, telling them to leave things alone, because I don't like the way they did something.  | guess the answer is to not be to proud , ask for help, and let husband and children know when you need help.  I guess we have to be more open with our feelings.

Overall it was not as bad as I had invisioned.  I wear a prothetis, and the biggest problem is getting a comfortable bra, reconstruction sounds like a good option, and am thinking about it.

Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Dec 24, 2010 09:20AM JustJudi wrote: My DH 's worst and best gift was when we were first married, I opened up a pair of panty hose, You can imagine the look on my face, then he informed me he had ordered a sewing machine for me, and it didn't arrive , so he ran around at the last moment to get something,  A few years later I received a laundry hamper.  He slowly got better over the years.  But I still remember those two presents.
Posts.Title: Your funniest/strangest holiday gift? EnglishMajor KarmaKittie

Posts.Content: Aug 15, 2014 06:15PM JustJudi wrote: Hi  I am 71, and like you, I feel bad for the younger members who are raising young families.  We all have our struggles, just different ones. My children are grown up with young families, but they still bring their problems and struggles home to me and ask for help in solving them  We are suppose to have so much wisdom and to them we are still their mother.   I am dealing with a husband recently retired, who has no clue what to do with himself, and has his own health issues, which I have to manage, as a go between with Drs, etc. because of poor hearing.   I often sit back and say what about me.   I apparently have to be the strong one, as told repeatedly by everyone, you are so strong and deal so well, frankly I don't have a choice,  I find even my husband who tells me to take it easy and rest, and asks how I am, would probably not  want to know that sometimes I feel like just quitting,  then feel guilty for thinking that way. I think our illness is different by the fact that we just don't have the energy and strength, that we did twenty years ago, so every thing is just harder.    WE are out their, I guess we are just not as verbal,    Judi
Posts.Title: Over 60 and Over 70 threads. Crone Crone

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2014 12:16PM JustJudi wrote: I have actually taken a break from xeloda for a couple of weeks, to give my feet and hands a chance to heal,  my blood work was just as good after three weeks when I went back on it.  My onc. stated that they will only get worse  and the pain of walking or standing doesnt help  So maybe ask if you can take a break, for a few weeks, to give them a chance to heal.  I end up using cocoa butter, coconut oil based products  aloe based, my dresser has about 6 different products, I noticed some gel slip on sockets  in the drugstore the other day, they could be wore with your shoes, and they recommended wearing them continually, they seemed to keep the moisture in and supply moisture at the same time, and apparently can be washed and last about a six weeks. thet were in pedicure section of the drugstore.  I will look for the name brand i forgot to write it down.
Posts.Title: Help with Xeloda side effects Connis jnh

Posts.Content: Jan 1, 2012 01:12PM JustJudi wrote: Great picture, I have decided that 2012 has got to be better, it has no choice, its not possible to be as bad as 2011  so EVERYONE HAVE A GREAT NEW YEAR
Posts.Title: A BRAND NEW YEAR! scuttlers lulubee

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2014 12:58PM JustJudi wrote: Their are options for pain control, I am actually on hydro morphine , i take one in morning and one at night, they are a slow release  and it keeps the pain under control. I find if I overdue it physically, I really pay for it the next day, So keep in mind you may have to be more careful and not exert yourself, Its hard because you feel you should be able to do everything you have always done,  But radiation can help if applied to the spine, or the area that is really bothering you, so get the xrays or scans,  talk to the onc. about your medication, and find one that  is more effective, there is better options then oxy.  Your personal care doctor should be working with your oncologist, and know what is going on , so they can provide the best care.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: Pain all the time? angiephnx springwatch

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2012 04:39PM JustJudi wrote: Right now I am staring out the window, at the snow coming down, it is -14 , and apparently we are getting the snow we have not had much of all winter, I find I have to force myself everyday to do the few household chores that need doing to make the house presentable, then I curl  up and stare mindlessly at the computer, I hope when spring comes, I can get more active, because life is passing me by . I wish I was 20 again, think of all the energy we had!!! Judi

Posts.Title: Bone Scan neogirl mthomp2020

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2010 12:29PM JustJudi wrote: When I first started treatments, my surgeon and radiologist were very negative, then when I met my oncologist, things began to look up, they started me on an active treatment program, and have the attitude that I have hopes for a future.  On my last visit I asked my Doctor whether I should be getting regular pap tests as part of my physical, as I wasn't sure if it was worthwhile. His comment was we need to treat you like any other healthy person, and make sure you are in the best health possible.  It gives you a feeling of yes, You have to do everything possible to prolong your life, not give up, keep on going.  Look for Doctors who will build you up and NOT drag you down.
Posts.Title: stage IV "discrimination"? jenny66 lindaa

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2013 03:19AM JustJudi wrote: I started out on Aromasine, and it worked for close to 4 years, then failed so I was put on Xeloda, which I have been on for 1 year,,  I was tired of the side effects, my hands were taking a beating, along with all the other lovely side effects, so last month I asked my onc. if I could try a hormonal again, so she said sure it has been known to work after being on chemo drugs so she put me on anastrozole,I will find out if it works when I go in for blood work in last part of January.  Frankly I am in dread hoping I didnt make a mistake.  But will find out, it would be nice to hear from ladies who have had success with this course of treatments .

Posts.Title: Can Bone Scans Differentiate Between Active Mets and Fractures? sdisilvestri EnglishMajor

Posts.Content: Mar 26, 2010 02:38AM JustJudi wrote: I was being treated for lower back pain for almost 6 months, before the doctors finally decided to investigate further, I had a bone density test , which showed I was well within the range for my age.  When I was finally found to have breast cancer , I had osteolytic bone mets to spine, hips and back.   They finally found these when I had an actual bone scan and MRI. I 've been on Aromasin for four months, and I have found the pain has almost disappeared during the day, aslong as I don't over do it. I also had 10 treatments of radiation to back early on which took away a lot of the pain. Wish you the best.  judi
Posts.Title: question about metastatic lesions on spine Mercedes57 33skidoo

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 10:38AM JustJudi wrote: I had this pain last year, it was pressure on the nerve from my spine, it was horrible at night, the pain was like having a blow torch held on your leg, and butt.  They treated it first with Gabapentin which helped to ease the pain by blocking the nerve pain, but didn,t cure the problem.  I had 14 bouts of radiation to my lower back for pain, as | had mets to spine, hips etc.  About 1 month after that the pain started to go away  and now one year later I am pain free. I guess the tumors either shrunk which stopped the pressure on the nerve, or the spine was not pressing on the nerve.  Have you had radiation, or do you have mets in that area? I hope you can get help to resolve this, as I know how painful it is.
Posts.Title: Butt & Leg Pain lukejessesmom lukejessesmom

Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2011 01:39AM JustJudi wrote: I was dealing with a great deal of burning pain in my leg last year because of disc issues, also had a lot of back pain.  But I felt the nerve pain was worse.  I had radiation to the back area that was causing the problem.  I am free of pain now , and no more nerve pain to the leg.  SO I would say it made a world of difference.

Hope you have good results and best wishes.
Posts.Title: Aromasin Jan244 mbk

Posts.Content: May 18, 2010 11:06AM JustJudi wrote: My onc. uses it as one of the many guides to in look for in the blood work. He watches to see if the markers are coming down , along with the rest of all the other tests, liver, proteins etc.  For me my tumor markers went from a high of 1476 to 296 in three months of taking aromisine. So he knew it was working.   App. if they get down to a normal range of around 19 or less, things are looking good.  Their are ladies on here that will have the answers for you . so hang in .

Posts.Title: Check-ups, how often? alicia_en_madrid JustJudi

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2014 01:38AM - edited Jun 27, 2014 01:39AM by JustJudi Have you been on any pain medications, and is your spine involved, radiation can help with pain. i hope you can get some relief, because being in constant pain can be very depressing. I have been on Xeloda for two years and it has kept things under control after aromasin quit working. Hope it will work for you and give you relief.
Posts.Title: Pain pain pain stellaratovsky bhd1

Posts.Content: Apr 28, 2010 12:35PM - edited Apr 28, 2010 12:36PM by JustJudi I was diagnosed in Aug/09 with a primary tumor in breast and a very small one just under the skin, but was told it had already spread to my spine, hip, etc. and I was stage four.  The surgeon recommended a modified radical mastectomy. The first question I asked him was why I should go through the surgery if I was already Stage four with mets.   He said after discussion with the committee at the Center, they were at the opinion that, they felt it was better to remove the source of the primary cancer, which would keep producing and spreading if radiation didn,t stop it.  But he also said if it had just been one tumor, they might have tried a different approach. But because I had another tiny one, it was better to  remove the tumors. I think each case has to be handled individually.
Posts.Title: No removal of breast tumor mohonda mohonda

Posts.Content: Apr 4, 2010 02:26AM JustJudi wrote: To bad you can't get transfered to HS Cancer Care.  I find them to be so professional their, and the resources at HS seem to be more readily available for the Drs. ordering scans etc.  I had my surgery At Seven Oaks. Hope your Dr. gets you going on the right treatment.  Best of luck. Judi
Posts.Title: NEED INFORMATION AND ADVICE imbell imbell

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2010 07:35AM - edited Apr 3, 2010 07:37AM by JustJudi I am in Wpg, too, but I have found you have to be the one to be aggresive in requesting a new doctor or making sure you are happy with your treatment, make a appointment with your family doctor and ask for them to refer you to a new onc.  If you have the name of someone , request they make the referral to that Dr.  I have had great care at Cancer Care, had some dealings with one Dr. who was very negative, but please ask the questions of the onc you are with now or like I said ask for a referral  good Drs don;t mind patients getting second opinions BEST OF LUCK  JUDI

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2010 08:39AM JustJudi wrote: I have mets to spine, hips, ribs etc.  and have for the past year had a lot of stiffness, my spine feels like a screw is being turned to tighten up the tension, always have a knot in back. i only have pain when I try and do to much, so can work for 15 min, then I have to rest my back.I have been using a walker for 8 months, my legs are strong,so hoping my spine will heal to a certain extent.  I am on Aromasine have just finished 6 months on it.  I don,t know your age, but I think I had some arthritis starting before diagnoisis. Sorry I have no answers for you other then to say it may be how mets work on the spine.   Judi
Posts.Title: stiffness assoicated with spinal mets mags123 ibcmets

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2014 01:38PM JustJudi wrote: Sorry you are going through this, i had the same thing happen last summer, it took a while to get on my feet, but by spring I was out of my wheelchair and walking. I don,t want to scare you, i had a lot of problems , because I had a rod in my arm so I couldnt use crutches, or walker for a while. But i know what a difficult feeling it is to not be mobile and able to do what you want. But hang in there, their is a rainbow at the end of this latest rain storm. I hope you a quick recovery , but don,t be discouraged, i had the radiation, and the bone just takes a little longer to heal then a normal so called healthy person, but it did heal, and I am walking again. Just get every one to wait on you and enjoy.

D and Calcium enough to keep my bones from further damage, this is a question I will ask him on my next visit, but would like to know what other ladies are doing and have you taken it longer then two years.  If you came off it after two years, what are you doing for bone maint.  Thankyou for imput. Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2014 06:48AM JustJudi wrote: Hi Bon, my walker is an older one with smaller wheels on it , but a wider seat, my daughter drives a focus and usually throws it in the back seat , best to put an old blanket on the seat..  My car is larger, and I manage to lift it into the trunk and it fits easily.  But my husband got a newer walker, and it has bigger wheels, is heavier, and has a small seat, and takes up a lot more room. You almost have to try them out by trying them in your car. I use my cane if I know I dont have to walk far, but find the walker more stable for long distances. Judi
Posts.Title: More Fun in CancerLand! justjudie

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 10:48AM JustJudi wrote: I have found recently that I don,t share much because then more questions follow and I don,t feel like getting into a long discussion with anyone. My DH will notice if I am in pain, and say why is your face screwed up, what,s wrong now, but I always have the feeling he would rather not know, so I just say my hip is hurting and leave it at that.  I have found with telling relatives anything, that the story gets changed so much, you wonder who they are talking about when it gets back to you, so I have decided to keep things to my self.  It is sometimes lonely when you can,t confide in anyone, but is less stressful to.  That is why I am trying to be an advocate for my children now as they start their journay dealing with cancer, give them a shoulder to cry on .

Posts.Title: More Fun in CancerLand! justjudie

Posts.Content: JustJudi wrote: When I was diagnosed in Aug, 2009, I started on a unknown path, I had suffered with back pain, and had to resort to using a cane in Dec 2008.  My doctor had referred me to a sports doctor, who treated it as old age, and  pills and didnt want to order tests.  Finally when my ribs started breaking in the spring, i went back to my regular Dr.  It wasn,t until Aug. i finally had a CT scan, Bone Scan and the BC was discovered.   After my mas. My surgeon informed me it had already mast. to my bones and I was stage iv . When  I was sent for radiation for back pain, The doctor I had insisted on telling me he could only give me pain relief and I needed to get pallative care in place. That I did not have a good outlook.  My onc. turned out to be more hopeful and started me on Aromasin, and Pamidronate to build up my bones.  My biggest concern was  the treatment agressive enough.  I was feeling really down, until I found this discussion board and started reading all the other stories, LADIES YOU GAVE ME HOPE, WHICH THE DOCTORS HADNT. I AM GREATFUL TO YOU. I just hope to be able to get rid of my walker, and get back to at least walking with a cane, i just retired a year ago and hoped to have freedom and fun.  My results have been great on the Aromasin and I am up beat. Dx 8/18/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 1/2 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2+ Hormonal Therapy 10/8/2009 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 2/6/2010 3DCRT: Bone Radiation Therapy 6/10/2012 Bone Chemotherapy 9/5/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Thank you for hope JustJudi katie11

Posts.Content: JustJudi wrote: Well went to bed at 10: last night, late movies don't work. try early bed time. take 2 ex str. tylenol and 1 oxc, lay back. wait-- try flipping to right side, lay on bump left by surgery, wait-- try flat on back, saute , gee its 12:30, hips start to kick in, whats with the pain relief, Go to bathroom, maybe that will help, flip to left side. Sleep - wake up , its 1:30, gee I had an hour, Get up turn down heat, go to bathroom, back to bed, what side? doze off, wake up , its now 2:40, hips still burning, try two more tylenol, stare at clock, flip and saute other side. It,s 3:40 take an oxc. I think the Dr. gave me the weakest dose available, all I get is dry mouth, Get more water, go bathroom, lay back,  Wake up its 6:40 I made it through another night, HELP, ANYONE OUT THERE GOT NEW RECIPES FOR SLEEP , YOU WANT TO SHARE. FLIPPING, SAUTE, AND SLOW COOKING DOESNT WORK. Dx 8/18/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 1/2 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2+ Hormonal Therapy 10/8/2009 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 2/6/2010 3DCRT: Bone Radiation Therapy 6/10/2012 Bone Chemotherapy 9/5/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: TIRED! TIRED! FLIPPING NEEDHELP JustJudi cmhartley

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2011 12:47PM JustJudi wrote: Two years ago, before being diagnosed with Breast Cancer, i had broke a rib from bending over dishwasher, and then cracked another one reaching for something, this is what drove me to the dr. to find out what was going on, as they had been treating me for back pain, and not coming up with any answers.  of course after scans they found out it had metastasised to my ribs, spine etc.  Finally after two years of treatment their has been some healing.  It is a warning sign   Judi
Posts.Title: Cracked Rib Robin75 Robin75

Posts.Content: May 6, 2014 12:11PM JustJudi wrote: I have been taking different treatments for four years now, and I find myself on a daily basis lately thinking about just stopping treatments for a while just to give myself a break.  I have had a two week rest from meds, and really didn't feel any better, as other side effects started to kick in, more pain, body aches etc.  and then it seems I have to start over.  I think that it depends on your health, age, and what is going on, is the cancer fairly aggressive, or is it not . I would ask my doctors opinion, and take it from their.  I know it is a very personal decision , and sometimes we just need a break, even for a few weeks, my Doctor always asks me if I want to continue, before we writes the next prescription, I don't know if she figures I am on the way out anyway, so give me the choice on how long I want to carry on, or if she is just wants to let me make the choices in my care.  It seems we always have to consider the effect on our families, if we have young children , on our husbands,  it is never easy, but sometimes we have to be selfish, and decide on how we what to handle our health, medications and treatments.Even if the Doctor allows you to take a few weeks off, to allow your body to rest, it may be a good option, at least you have a choice.  Best of Luck
Posts.Title: Taking a break ChicagoGirl Rosevalley

Posts.Content: Jan 12, 2012 12:18PM JustJudi wrote: This is the type of post I want to see, someone winning, congrats on your good news. We are all happy for you.
Posts.Title: Survivor Guilt - I am a lucky girl Fitztwins nancyh

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2010 10:36PM JustJudi wrote: I really think you should get this looked at, if your present Dr. isnt concerned find a new one. I didn't have the discharge, but 4 years ago, after badly bruising my breast from a mammo. I had a some dime sized lump just under the skin below the nipple.  The Dr.sent me to the Breast clinic to have it looked at, and the Dr. said it didn't need a biopsy because it was just under the skin.  Three years later, it started moving, got quite dry and the skin cracked.  I also developed a large lump in the milk gland and so when | went and got a biopsy on it, they also did the smaller lump that I had and found it had developed cancer.  The nipple was also inverted during this time.This is not unusal in itself, but could be a clue  that something is going on.  So please go and have it checked to make sure that it is not just an infection.  Best of luck.
Posts.Title: maybe someone can help me out here mykidsmomma Jaydra

Posts.Content: JustJudi wrote: This question is about my daughter, she is in the middle of her chemo right now, and has 3 more to go. The doctors want her to quit work, she is in a school , but not in regular classroom setting, one on one to one student in a private room.  She has come down with a viral infection, and ended up in hospital, because she hasnt been able to eat. So she is on fluids right now.  Her problem is that she is that she needs another month of work to get enough hours to qualify for benefits.  She has a five year old that is in the school system and is probably going to be carrying more germs, virus and everything going from her classroom.  The question is has anyone worked while doing chemo and been able to advoid contacting every bug that goes around.  She would like to try and get her hours in but not at any costs.  She knows her health comes first, but she also has to live, and one salary at home doesnt cut it anymore.  Anyone have this problem Dx 8/18/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, Grade 2, 1/2 nodes, mets, ER+, HER2+ Hormonal Therapy 10/8/2009 Aromasin (exemestane) Radiation Therapy 2/6/2010 3DCRT: Bone Radiation Therapy 6/10/2012 Bone Chemotherapy 9/5/2012 Xeloda (capecitabine) Log in to post a reply
